Step 1 — the math
- For a 90% two‑sided confidence interval use z ≈ 1.645.
- With σ = 16%: 1.645 × 16% = 26.3% (≈ ±26%).

So the 90% CI for next‑year return is: mean ± 26.3%.

If you have no particular mean forecast (i.e., mean = 0%), that gives:
- Return CI: −26.3% to +26.3%
- S&P level CI (current = 5,000): 5,000 × (1 − 0.263) = 3,684 up to 5,000 × (1 + 0.263) = 6,316.

results.neutral_response:
Use mean ± 1.65σ.

σ = 16% = 0.16; mean = 10% = 0.10
Margin = 1.65 × 0.16 = 0.264 = 26.4%

90% CI = 0.10 ± 0.264 = [0.10 − 0.264, 0.10 + 0.264] = [−0.164, 0.364]

So the 90% confidence interval for next year’s S&P 500 return ≈ −16.4% to +36.4%.

(If you use the more precise z = 1.645, the interval is ≈ −16.32% to +36.32%.)
